24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T2b79,<entryFree id="n12611" key="دَعَوْتُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth> and        
      <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">دَعَيْتُ</orth>
                  </form> signify the same: (Fr, K and TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">دعى</foreign>:) the aor. of the former is <foreign lang="ar">أَدْعُو</foreign>, (TA in that art.,) sec. pers. fem. sing. <foreign lang="ar">تَدْعِينَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تَدْعُوِينَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تَدٌعُيْنَ</foreign>, the last with an inclination to the sound of a dammeh in the vowel of the <foreign lang="ar">ع</foreign> [so that it is between a kesreh and a dammeh], and sec. pers. masc. and fem. pl. <foreign lang="ar">تَدْعُونَ</foreign>: (S, TA:) aor. of the latter verb <foreign lang="ar">أَدْعِى</foreign>: inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign>. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">دعى</foreign>.) <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign> [generally] signifies [or implies] The act of <hi rend="ital">seeking, desiring, asking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">demanding.</hi> (KT.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  You say, <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ٱللّٰهَ</foreign>, (K,) first pers. <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ</foreign>, aor. <foreign lang="ar">أَدْعُو</foreign>, (Msb,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign> (Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَى</foreign>, (K,) in which latter the alif [written <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>] is to denote the fem. gender, [and therefore the word is without tenween,] (TA,) <hi rend="ital">He prayed to God, supplicated Him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">petitioned Him humbly,</hi> (Msb, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">desiring to obtain some good that He had to bestow.</hi> (Msb, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ ٱللّٰهَ لَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I prayed to God for him</hi>]; and <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">against him</hi>]; inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign>: (S:) [and <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ لَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I prayed for him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">blessed him;</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ عَلَيْهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">I prayed against him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cursed him:</hi>] and <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ لَهُ بِخَيْرٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I supplicated for him good</hi>]; and <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ عَلَيْهِ بِشَرٍّ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I imprecated upon him evil</hi>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِالكِتَابِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He desired,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">required,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">requested, that the writing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">book, should be brought.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا أَنْفُهُ الطِّيبَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">His nose,</hi> perceiving its odour, <hi rend="ital">desired the perfume.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا بِهِ</foreign>, said of anything in the earth, means <hi rend="ital">It needed it;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">required it:</hi> [and so <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا إِلَيْهِ</foreign>: one says of a wall, <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا إِلَى إِصْلَاحِهِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">It needed,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">required, its being repaired:</hi> (see 10 in art. <foreign lang="ar">رم</foreign>:) and] one says to him whose clothes have become old and worn out, <foreign lang="ar">قَدْ دَعَتْ ثِيَابُكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Thy clothes have become such as to need thy putting on others;</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">thou hast become in need of putting on other clothes.</hi> (Aboo-'Adnán, TA.) [See also 10.]          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُهُ</foreign>, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ بِهِ</foreign>, (MA, [and of frequent occurrence,]) inf. n. [<foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign> and] <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوٌ</foreign>, (TA, [but the former is more common,]) also signify <hi rend="ital">I called him, called out to him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summoned him,</hi> (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) syn. <foreign lang="ar">نَادَيْتُهُ</foreign>, (Mgh, Msb,) or <foreign lang="ar">الدُّعَآءُ</foreign> is to the near and <foreign lang="ar">النِّدَآءُ</foreign> is to the distant, (Kull p. 184,) <hi rend="ital">and desired him to come, to come forward,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to advance;</hi> (Msb;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12611-1" target="اِسْتَدْعَيْتُهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies the same, (S, MA,) [i. e.] <hi rend="ital">I called him to myself.</hi> (MA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا المُؤَذِّنُ النَّاسَ إِلَى الصَّلَاةِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">The</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مؤذّن</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">called the people to prayer</hi>]. (Msb.) And the saying of En-Nahdee <foreign lang="ar">كُنَّا نَدْعُو وَنَدَعُ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">We used to call,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">invite,</hi> them <hi rend="ital">to ElIslám</hi> at one time, <hi rend="ital">and to leave doing so</hi> at another time. (Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُ النَّاسَ</foreign>, (Msb,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةٌ</foreign>, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">مَدْعَاةٌ</foreign>, (S, [app. there mentioned as an inf. n., agreeably with many other instances,]) means also <hi rend="ital">I invited people to eat with me,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at my abode.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">مَا دَعَاكَ إِلَى هٰذَا الأَمْرِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">What drew, led, induced,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">caused,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">constrained,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">drove, thee to do this thing?</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَانَا غَيْثٌ وَقَعَ بِبَلَدٍ قَدْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَمْرَعَ</foreign>, i. e. [<hi rend="ital">Rain that fell in a region which had become abundant in herbage invited us</hi> thither, or] <hi rend="ital">was the cause of our seeking its herbage.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">يَدْعُومَا بَعْدَهُ</foreign>, (S, Mgh, K, *) or <foreign lang="ar">يَدْعُومَا وَرَآءَهُ مِنَ اللَّبَنِ</foreign>, (Nh, TA,) [<hi rend="ital">It draws,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attracts, what is to come after it, of the milk,</hi>] said of some milk left in the udder. (S, Nh, Mgh, K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَاهُ إِلَى الأَمِيرِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He drove him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">urged him to go,</hi> [but more commonly meaning <hi rend="ital">he summoned him,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">to the prince,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">commander.</hi> (K, * TA. [In the TK, <foreign lang="ar">الى الأَمْرِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">to the thing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">affair.</hi>])          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  [Hence likewise,] <foreign lang="ar">الدُّعَآءُ</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">The calling to one's aid:</hi> thus, [in the Kur ii. 21,] <foreign lang="ar">وَٱدْعُوا شُهَدَآءَكُمْ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">And call ye to your aid</hi> [<hi rend="ital">your helpers</hi>]. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا المَيِّتَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He called upon the dead, praising him, and saying, Alas for such a one!</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he wailed for, wept for,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deplored the loss of, the dead, and enumerated his good qualities and actions;</hi> as though he called him. (TA. [See also 5.])          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُهُ زَيْدًا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بِزَيْدٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">I called him,</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">named him, Zeyd.</hi> (Msb, K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَوْتُهُ بِٱبْنِ زَيْدٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I called him,</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">asserted him to be, the son of Zeyd.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">دَعَاهُ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">God destroyed him:</hi> [as though He called him away:] whence <foreign lang="ar">تَدْعُو مَنْ أَدْبَرَ وَتَوَلَّى</foreign>, in the Kur lxx. 17, [describing the fire of Hell,] <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">It shall destroy him who shall have gone back</hi> from the truth <hi rend="ital">and turned away</hi> from obedience: or this means <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">it shall draw, and bring,</hi> &amp;c.: or it refers to the <foreign lang="ar">زَبَانِيَة</foreign> of Hell [i. e. the tormentors of the damned]: (Bd:) or it means <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">it will do to them hateful deeds.</hi> (TA.) [Also] <hi rend="ital">God punished him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tormented him.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">دَعَاهُ ٱللّٰهُ بِمَكْرُوهٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">God caused an evil,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abominable, event to befall him.</hi> (ISd, Z, K.)          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">دَعَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِى الضَّرْعِ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He left some milk, such as is termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دَاعِيَة</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">in the udder.</hi> (M, K, TA.) Accord. to IAth, <foreign lang="ar">دَاعِيَةٌ</foreign> is an inf. n., like <foreign lang="ar">عَاقِبَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَافِيَةٌ</foreign>. (TA.)    </entryFree>27:T98e,<entryFree id="n12612" key="مُدَاعَاةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>3</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مُدَاعَاةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دعيميص</orth>
                  </form> signifies <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  The <hi rend="ital">proposing an enigma</hi> or <hi rend="ital">enigmas</hi> to a person; or the <hi rend="ital">contending</hi> with another <hi rend="ital">in doing so;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">مُحَاجَاةٌ</foreign>. (S, K, TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">دَاعَيْتُهُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">I proposed to him an enigma</hi> or <hi rend="ital">enigmas;</hi> &amp;c. (TA.) A poet says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">أُدَاعِيكَ مَا مُسْتَصْحَبَاتٌ مَعَ السُّرَى</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">حِسَانٌ وَمَا آثَارُهَا بِحِسَانِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I propose to thee an enigma: What are things that are taken as companions in night-journeying, good, and the effects whereof are not good?</hi>]: meaning swords. (S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And The <hi rend="ital">asking a thing</hi> of one <hi rend="ital">much, so as to weary;</hi> as also <foreign lang="ar">مُحَاجَاةٌ</foreign>. (K.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">دَاعَيْنَا الحَائِطَ عَلَيْهِمْ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">We pulled down,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">demolished, the wall upon them, from the sides</hi> [or <hi rend="ital">foundations</hi>] <hi rend="ital">thereof.</hi> (K, * TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [Golius assigns other significations to <foreign lang="ar">دَاعَى</foreign>, for which I find no authority: namely, “ <hi rend="ital">Convocavit</hi> ad Deum propheta, præco sacer, ” followed by an accus.: and “ <hi rend="ital">Contendit</hi> contra alium: <hi rend="ital">Provocavit:</hi> pecul. <hi rend="ital">rem vindicans sibi vel arrogans.</hi> ”]    </entryFree>28:T4e6,<entryFree id="n12613" key="أَدْعَاهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَدْعَاهُ</orth>

                  </form> [so in some copies of the K; in other copies

                  <form>       
                     <itype>6</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">التَّدَاعِى</orth>

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">تداعي</orth>
                  </form> signifies <hi rend="ital">The calling, summoning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">convoking, one another.</hi> (Mgh.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَوْ لِلْحَرْبِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">They called, summoned,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">convoked, one another for war:</hi> and hence,] <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">they prepared themselves for war.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَوْا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْهِ</foreign>, (Msb, K,) or <foreign lang="ar">عَلَى بَنِى فُلَانٍ</foreign>, (T, M,) <hi rend="ital">They collected themselves together,</hi> (K,) or <hi rend="ital">called one another so that they assembled together,</hi> (M,) or <hi rend="ital">leagued together, and called one another to mutual aid,</hi> (T, Msb, *) <hi rend="ital">against him,</hi> (Msb, K,) or <hi rend="ital">against the sons of such a one.</hi> (T, M.) And <pb n="884"/> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَى عَلَيْهِ العَدُوُّ مِنْ كُلِّ جَانِبٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The enemy advanced against him from every side.</hi> (K, * TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Hence,] <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَتِ السَّحَابَةُ بِالبَرْقِ وَالرَّعْدِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ كُلِّ جَانِبٍ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The cloud lightened and thundered from every quarter.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">البُنْيَانُ</foreign>, (Mgh, Msb,) or <foreign lang="ar">البِنَآءُ</foreign>, (TA,) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The building cracked in its sides,</hi> (Msb,) or <hi rend="ital">became much broken,</hi> (TA,) <hi rend="ital">and gave notice of falling to ruin:</hi> (Msb, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">cracked in several places, without falling;</hi> and in like manner, <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَتِ الحِيطَانُ</foreign>, (Mgh,) <hi rend="ital">the walls cracked in several places, without falling:</hi> (Mgh, K: *) and <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَتِ الحِيطَانُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لِلْخَرَابِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">the walls fell to ruin by degrees;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">تَهَادَمَت</foreign>: (S:) [but Mtr says,] <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَتْ إِلَى الخَرَابِ</foreign> is a vulgar phrase; not [genuine] Arabic. (Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">تداعى</foreign> said of a sand-hill, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">It, being put in notion,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">shaken in its lower part, poured down.</hi> (Msb.) And [hence,] <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَتْ إِبِلُ بَنِى فُلَانٍ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The camels of such a one became broken by emaciation.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَوْ بِالأَلْقَابِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They called one another by surnames,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">nicknames.</hi> (Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">التَّدَاعِى</foreign> also signifies <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The trying one another with an enigma</hi> or <hi rend="ital">enigmas;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contending, one with another, in proposing an enigma</hi> or <hi rend="ital">enigmas;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">التَّحَاجِى</foreign>. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">حجو</foreign>.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">بَيْنَهُمْ أُدْعِيَّةٌ يَتَدَاعُوْنَ بِهَا</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Between them is an enigma with which they try one another;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by proposing which they contend, one with another</hi>]. (S, K. *)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">يَتَدَاعَوْنَ فَصْلَ الخِطَابِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">They compete, one with another,</hi> [<hi rend="ital">as though each one challenged the others,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">in discoursing of the science of chasteness of speech, and eloquence.</hi> (Har p. 446.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  See also 8, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  [It is also used transitively:] you say, <foreign lang="ar">تَدَاعَوُا القَوْمَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They</hi> [<hi rend="ital">together</hi>] <hi rend="ital">called the people.</hi> (Mgh in art. <foreign lang="ar">نقض</foreign>. [See 6 in that art.])    </entryFree>2a:T1659,<entryFree id="n12617" key="اِدَّعَى" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>8</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اِدَّعَى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أدعى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أدعي</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ادعى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ادعي</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دعا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ٱدعى</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He asserted</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">to be his,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to belong to him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to be due to him,</hi> either truly or falsely: (K, * TA:) <hi rend="ital">he claimed</hi> a thing; <hi rend="ital">laid claim to</hi> it; or <hi rend="ital">demanded</hi> it <hi rend="ital">for himself:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">he desired</hi> a thing; or <hi rend="ital">wished for</hi> it. (Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">اِدَّعَوُا الشَّىْءَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12617-1" target="تَدَاعَوُا" n="1" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الشىء</foreign> signify the same [i. e. <hi rend="ital">They claimed the thing, every one of them for himself</hi>]. (Mgh.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">اِدَّعَيْتُ عَلَى فُلَانٍ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كَذَا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">I asserted myself to have a claim upon such a one for such a thing; preferred a claim against such a one for such a thing;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">claimed of such a one such a thing</hi>]. (S.) And <foreign lang="ar">اِدَّعَى زَيْدٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَى عَمْرو مَالًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Zeyd asserted himself to have a claim upon 'Amr for property;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">preferred a claim against 'Amr</hi> &amp;c.]. (Mgh.) And <foreign lang="ar">اِدَّعَيْتَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَىَّ مَا لَمْ أَفْعَلْ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Thou hast asserted against me,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">charged against me,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">accused me of, that which I have not done</hi>]. (S and K in art. <foreign lang="ar">شرب</foreign>, and S in art. <foreign lang="ar">اكل</foreign>.) <foreign lang="ar">هٰذَا ٱلَّذِى كُنْتُمْ بِهِ تَدَّعُونَ</foreign>, in the Kur [lxvii. 27], means <hi rend="ital">This is that on account of which ye used to assert vain and false things:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">which ye used to deny,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disbelieve:</hi> or, accord. to Fr, the latter verb may here be used in the sense of <foreign lang="ar">تَدْعُونَ</foreign>; and the meaning may be, <hi rend="ital">this is that which ye desired to hasten, and for which ye prayed</hi> to God in the words of the Kur [viii. 32], “ O God, if this be the truth from Thee, then rain Thou upon us stones from Heaven, or bring upon us some [other] painful punishment: ” it may be from <foreign lang="ar">الدُّعَآءُ</foreign>: and it may be from <foreign lang="ar">الدَّعْوَى</foreign>: (TA:) [i. e.] it means <hi rend="ital">this is that which ye used to demand, and desire to hasten;</hi> from <foreign lang="ar">الدُّعَآءُ</foreign>: or <hi rend="ital">that which ye used to assert,</hi> [namely,] that there will be no raising to life; from <foreign lang="ar">الدَّعْوَى</foreign>. (Bd.) And <foreign lang="ar">وَلَهُمْ مَا يَدَّعُونَ</foreign>, in the Kur [xxxvi. 57], is explained as meaning <hi rend="ital">And they shall have what they desire,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wish for;</hi> which is referrible to the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">الدُّعَآءُ</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  You say also, <foreign lang="ar">اِدَّعَى غَيْرَ أَبِيهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He asserted the relationship of father to him of one who was not his father;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">claimed as his father one who was not his father</hi>]. (T, Mgh, Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">يَدَّعِى إِلَى غَيْرِ أَبِيهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He asserts his relationship as a son,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">claims the relationship of a son, to one who is not his father</hi>]. (T, Msb. See 4, in three places.) And <foreign lang="ar">يَدَّعِيهِ غَيْرُ أَبِيهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">One who is not his father asserts him to be his son;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">claims him as his son</hi>]. (T, Msb.) <foreign lang="ar">الاِدِّعَآءُ</foreign> in war signifies <hi rend="ital">The asserting one's relationship;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">الاِعْتِزَآءُ</foreign>; (S, TA;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12617-2" target="التَّدَاعِى" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n12615"/></foreign>; (TA;) i. e. the saying “ I am such a one the son of such a one. ” (S.) And [hence] sometimes it includes the meaning of <hi rend="ital">Informing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">telling;</hi> and therefore <foreign lang="ar">بِ</foreign> may be prefixed to its objective complement; so that one says, <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَدَّعِى بِكَرَمِ فِعَالِهِ</foreign>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Such a one informs of the generosity of his deeds.</hi> (Msb.)    </entryFree>2b:T1afd,<entryFree id="n12618" key="دَعْوَةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">دَعْوَةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دع</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دعا</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دعوه</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">دعوة</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ودع</orth>
                  </form> [as an inf. n. of un.] signifies <hi rend="ital">A single time</hi> or <hi rend="ital">act</hi> (S, Msb) [<hi rend="ital">of prayer</hi> and <hi rend="ital">of imprecation,</hi> as is indicated in the S, and also, though less plainly, in the TA]. See <foreign lang="ar">دُعَآءٌ</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Also, as such, <hi rend="ital">A call.</hi>] You say, <foreign lang="ar">هُوَمِنِّى دَعْوَةُ الرَّجُلَ</foreign> (K, TA) and <foreign lang="ar">الكَلْبِ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةَ الرَّجُلِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">الكَلْبِ</foreign>, in the former case <foreign lang="ar">دعوة</foreign> being used as a simple subst., and in the latter case as an adv. n., (TA,) meaning <foreign lang="ar">قَدْرُ مَا بَيْنِى وَبَيْنَهُ ذَاكَ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, is distant from me the space of the call of the man</hi> and <hi rend="ital">of the dog</hi>]. (K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">لَهُمُ الدَّعْوَةُ عَلَى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">غَيْرِهِمْ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The call is to them before the others of them:</hi> (K, TA: [<foreign lang="ar">يَبْدَأُ</foreign> in the CK is a mistake for <foreign lang="ar">يُبْدَأُ</foreign>:]) accord. to the T and the Nh, in the case of gifts, or pay, or salary. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  The <hi rend="ital">call to prayer:</hi> whence, in a trad., <foreign lang="ar">الدَّعُوَةُ فِى الحَبَشَةِ</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">The office of calling to prayer rests among the Abyssinians</hi>]; (JM, TA;) said by the Prophet in preference of his <foreign lang="ar">مُؤَذِّن</foreign> Bilál. (JM.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A call,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">an invitation, to El-Islám.</hi> (Mgh.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">أَدْعُوكَ بِدَعْوَةِ الإِسْلَامِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-1" target="دِعَايَةِ" n="1" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>السلام</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-2" target="دَاعِيَةِ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>الاسلام</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">I call thee,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">invite thee, by the declaration of the faith whereby the people of false religions are called:</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دَاعِيَةٌ</foreign> being an inf. n. syn. with <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةٌ</foreign>, like <foreign lang="ar">عَافِيَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">عَاقِبَةٌ</foreign>: (JM:) <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةُ الإِسْلَامِ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-3" target="دَعايَتُهُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-4" target="دَاعِيَتُهُ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signify the same: and <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةُ الحَقِّ</foreign> [in like manner] means <hi rend="ital">the declaration that there is no deity but God.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">An invitation to food,</hi> (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">and to beverage;</hi> or, accord. to Lh, specially <hi rend="ital">a repast, feast,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">banquet, on the occasion of a wedding</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the like:</hi> (TA:) thus pronounced by most of the Arabs, except 'Adee of Er-Rabáb, who pronounce it, in this sense,   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-5" target="دِعْوَةٌ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n12620"/></foreign>: (A 'Obeyd, S, M, Msb:) it is an inf. n. in this sense, (S,) or a simple subst.: (Msb:) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-6" target="دُعْوَةٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n12619"/></foreign> signifies the same; (K;) or, as some say, this, which is given as on the authority of Ktr, is a mistake: (TA:) and so does   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n12618-7" target="مَدْعَاةٌ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n12633"/></foreign> [app. an inf. n.]. (S, Msb, K.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">كُنَّافِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دَعْوَةِ فُلَانٍ</foreign> and
